most.translation[0].definitions[0].type: used before an adjective or adverb to form the superlative
most.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: having the greatest amount of a particular quality
most.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She’s one of the most experienced teachers in the district.
The most important thing is to stay calm.
A recent study showed that gardening is easily the most popular activity among the over 50s.
We shall find out which system works most effectively.
It is the kind of tea most often served in Chinese restaurants.
most.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: Most is not used before the -est form of an adjective or adverb You say
This exercise is one of the hardest
This exercise is one of the most hardest
most.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to a greater degree or more times than anything else
most.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: What annoyed him most was the way she wouldn’t even listen.
I guess the food I eat most is pasta.
Most of all, I just felt sad that it was over.
most.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Thank you for a most interesting evening.
I was most surprised to hear of your engagement.
most.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: He plays poker most every evening.
most.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: USAGE: The most, the more
most.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You use the most  when you are comparing one person or thing with all others
It was the most terrifying experience of my life
most.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: In spoken English, you can also use the most  when comparing just two people or things  However, some people think that this is incorrect and use (the) more to compare two people or things
Which is the most enjoyable – tennis or squash?
Which is the more enjoyable – tennis or squash?
most.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: nearly all of the people or things in a group, or nearly all of something
most.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Like most people, I try to take a vacation every year.
Most research in this field has been carried out by the Russians.
Some were barefoot, most were in rags.
Most of the time it’s very quiet here.
most of the time/most days etc
Most evenings we just stay in and watch TV.
most of the time/most days etc
It was Sunday and most of the shops were shut.
Most of what Hannah told me wasn’t true.
most.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a larger amount or number than anyone or anything else
most.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The animal that caused most trouble was a little black puppy.
The team that scores the most points wins.
Which class has the most children in it?
It’s unfair that you should have to pay the most when you earn so little.
most.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: the largest number or amount possible
most.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The aim is to help patients to obtain most benefit from their treatment.
The most you can hope to achieve is just to get him to listen to your ideas.
most.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Patterns with most
most.translation[1].note_box[0].items[0]: You use most before plural nouns to talk about people or things in general
most.translation[1].note_box[0].items[1]: Most of the shops are closed
most.translation[1].note_box[0].items[2]: You say most of my/her/his etc or many of them/us/you
Most of my friends are at university
most.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: the northernmost town in Sweden  (=the town that is furthest to the north)
the topmost branches of the tree
